content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice clash, with an optimal level of difficulty IMO. It took me almost 5 minutes in Python because of operator precedence.
Debugging taught me that:
 -1 ** k != (-1) ** k

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Approved because it is straightforward, but still requires some computations to be done. This will make a fine challenge!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: good problem for shortest mode and tests your number theory. managed to get 44 characters in ruby since the testcases are fixed now.
update: i reduced it down to 43 characters now.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
Seems good to me. I also agree with NicknamedTwice's comment.

Hi !

Nice problem, one little thing that might help some people would be to add a little note for C++/C, etc... developers to use a big int type, like unsigned long long.
But maybe this is part of the problem, and the users have to search 20! to realize that it is to big for a simple int. I don't really know.

Thank you for the problem !

i suggest you add something like this when you describe the formula to make it easier to understand for some people:
or in simpler terms like:
!N = N! * (sum from k=0 to N of ((-1)^k / k!))

i have tried golfing it in ruby but only managed 95 characters, which could probably be improved by some better players :)

Your answers for N = 19 and N = 20 seem wrong. Please refer to: https://oeis.org/A000166/list

Thanks.

unsigned long limit is 2^64 - 1 = 18 446 744 073 709 551 615
20! = 2 432 902 008 176 640 000 is more than 7 times fewer.
